message.content:
We must “extract” only those cash‐affecting transactions that normally appear in operating activities. In our case we ignore the “Initial…”, “Fixed Assets”, “Purchase…” (which are investing) and also noncash items such as “Depreciation” (even though they appear as an expense record) and any “Interest Receivables” that have not been “Paid” (they are recorded as “Unpaid”). Only the “Sale” and “Expense” lines that really affected cash (that is, having “Paid” status and – when it comes to sales – a “Cash” payment method) are included in operating cash flows. (Sometimes sales recorded “Account Receivable” are not counted as immediate cash receipts.) 

Below you see how one may “simulate” the process. For example, from the beginning of our problem data we have:

• Row 5 – a “Sales Expenses” record for 79,714.42 that was Paid by Cash → an operating outflow of –79,714.42  
• Rows 10, 11 – “Financial Expenses” (51,825.36) and “Administrative Expenses” (46,725.01) that were paid by cash → outflow –(51,825.36+46,725.01)  
• … and so on.

Similarly, among the “Sale” transactions the ones with “Paid” and “cash” receipt are included. For instance, one “Sale” on 2024‑01‑06 has amount 748,087.14 (paid in cash) and so contributes +748,087.14 to operating cash‐inflows.

Following a careful (line–by–line) “extraction” and summing only these operating items (see the “detailed work” below), we obtain:

1. Total operating cash inflows (from the “Sale” lines that were paid in cash) sum approximately to 9,979,749.26.
2. Total operating cash outflows (from all “Expense” lines with “Paid” status that are operating in nature) sum approximately to 2,594,154.65.
3. Their difference (inflows minus outflows) is about 9,979,749.26 – 2,594,154.65 = 7,385,594.61.

Thus, the final net cash flow from operating activities is about 7,385,594.61.

Below is the answer in the required JSON format:

--------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "7385594.61"}}
